body:
n.b. most of the additional lines are top-level directory duplications to work around the lack of namespace package support in auditwheel (and, in a strange twist of fate, this hack works with wheels, but not with installing from source, so `build_python.sh` needs to do a double-install-dance, but users won't). Those particular additions are not _necessary_ for this PR per se, but I found it easier to fix them in this lump of work rather than after the fact.

The only tests I'm unsure about succeeding are the performance smoke tests. Following that the DNM will be removed and reviewers assigned.
I... _dislike_... Mac OS X and it's almost-being-Linux-but-everyone-treating-it-slightly-differently-cascading-into-my-face. It is... _unpleasant_.
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle This was basically what I rebased your commits on top of for debugging poirposes :dolphin:.

"Make running individual Python tests less painful" is too brief a commit log message - may I trouble you for "before, the difficulty was ..." and "with this change, the developer experience is ..." embellishments?
How exactly is running individual python tests painful? Are you aware you can do run_tests.py -l python -r REGEX   where regex is matched against the name of the python test?

Btw, ./tools/run_tests/build_python.sh is not something you should invoke yourself (at least that's the idea for other languages and I don't think python should be different).  If you want to just build, you can run run_tests.py --build_only, which is going to work well for other languages as well.

@jtattermusch The output gets eaten on interrupt, the PID of the process has to be guessed at so GDB attachment takes some guesswork on each run, and working around any of those requires an encyclopedic knowledge of our environment variable names. These details will be added in the updated commit message.

@jtattermusch Build-only might be available as an option on `run_tests`, yes, but the point is that whatever it generates at the current time results in a mishmash of difficulties for getting something as simple as process attachment via `gdb` (or `cygdb`, which is also indirectly addressed here; `run_tests` doesn't provide debug options to generate the virtualenvs while build_python.sh is low-enough-level that it can by invoking against the right python build [usually `python-dbg`]). Even if I wanted to modify `run_tests` to work with `--build_only` for debugging purposes, `build_python.sh` would still need the additional capabilities to handle that (and that's what's shown here).
Rebased. Also removed `tox` as it's now unused.

Also the changes up through ecc3cfa will play a major role in getting the Python-on-Windows tests to work on Jenkins<sup><IN>Because <NNS>indirect-things-cascading-into-everything-else</sup> (coming soon to a PR near you).

I'm not fully convinced that putting unit tests in a separate module is best way to go.  In most (all) python modules I've encountered, unit tests get packaged with the module they test.  I can't find much discussion of the pros/cons to this approach online, so to be solidly convinced this is the way we should be doing things, I would need more information around what specifically doesn't work, and why a separate package is the best (or only) way to solve that problem.

The two problems that I understand are addressed here are Windows testing and gdb support.  I don't have much context for the Windows issues, and it seems like the `build_python.sh` changes combined with `gdb --args python <unit-test>` is sufficient to use gdb on a unit test.   

Also, I think we should hold off on merging this until the namespace issues that cause us to duplicate large chunks of code into grpcio_tools are resolved.

@kpayson64 Funny thing is, that is the exact same argument I used when we first moved the tests into the grpcio project.

I'd be convinced again by it now if we didn't find it so natural to e.g. test multiple projects within a single project. The grpcio-tools tests use some infrastructure from grpcio tests, for example, and same with the health-checking tests using features from wherever elsewhere (so already we have some dependency inversions when moving between our distributions and our tests). At one point it was similar to that but vice versa (except code generation passes were intermittent manual things rather than part of the test, see `_junkdrawer`). A strong example is the use of grpcio-tools in the tests to regenerate test protos. Yes, this is 'well defined', but by no means is it 'clean' to have such a dependency inversion.

Additionally, the plugin test code has demonstrably tested and revealed bugs in the grpcio test code far, far more times than it has revealed bugs in code generation. It isn't a plugin test. It's a primary use case of the grpcio project, but one whose primary projects (grpcio-tools and grpcio) _must_ be split apart.

I'm with you on the file duplication thing, except with a sidenote: these changes **do not** introduce the problem being ostensibly solved by the duplication. The problem was inteoduced when we decided a month ago to put files at the top level and when we discovered `auditwheel` didn't support namespace packages due to a bug (pypa/auditwheel#37).
Rebased to remove the duplication; I'll just look into fixing `auditwheel` instead.

Yet more detail, please? Has the command to run a single Python test changed?

There's a lot here - how possible would it be to break this change into multiple pull requests?

@nathanielmanistaatgoogle Messages have been updated.

I imagine that the individual commits can be split apart, but going to a finer resolution than that may involve some non-trivial teasing-apart-of-changes.
Python test failures in Windows are irrelevant (see #6797).

Milestoning this for GA because it's part of the lead-up to getting Windows tests running, which is part of the lead-up to getting Windows tests debuggable, which is part of the lead-up to figuring out and fixing the failing Windows tests in #6797.
Marking P1 because the previous comment basically warrants a priority label by transitivity with our Windows test failures (we're _distributing_ Windows wheels, so we _should_ be green on Windows).
Rebased.
I've made some comments.  I'm fine with pulling the tests into a separate package even if its not my first choice.
Also, probably out of the scope of this pr, but we should merge grpcio_health_checking to use shared grpc namespace now that it works.
Agreed on the shared `grpc` namespace, but that's after #6811.
lgtm
Luhguhtum.
Basic tests are too red. I'm not convinced at all this is safe to merge.
@jtattermusch  basic tests for Python on Windows is a holdover for a different PR.

Let's make sure we're all talking about the same burden of proof: we believe that a change is safe to merge when the four cells of Python-by-(x86, x64)-by-(Linux, MacOS) are green, right? And Python-by-(x86, x64)-by-Windows is known to be not yet passing in all contexts (like, say, [gRPC master](https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/job/gRPC_master/), for one example)?

Well this one is also touching non-python specific files  like run_tests.py  and others, so potentially lots of harm can be done. Let's be careful (normally if you are only touching files under src/python I can be convinced that only the python cells in the matrix are relevant). Also, if there's ~10 non-green cells in the entire build that can potentially be related, I really don't feel like manually checking all of them to make sure things are ok. I have many other PRs in the queue and if I had to do this for all of them, this would become my day job basically.
After merging other PRs this needs resolving anyway.
